questions.text: Which of the following is a crucial element involved in activating the complement through the alternative pathway?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - C3:

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes

C1q (Option A ruled out), C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4 (Option D ruled out), C2 (Option B ruled out), C3 convertase

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naïve T-cells ?
What type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the hyperacute rejection of kidney transplants?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Type II

questions.text: CD4 T-cell activation is done by?
questions.explanation:
Feature

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expression

Found on almost all nucleated cells

Found mainly on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells

Antigen Source

Presents intracellular antigens (e.g., viral or tumor proteins)

Presents extracellular antigens (e.g., bacterial peptides)

Interacts With

CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells)

CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells)

Main HLA Genes

HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C

HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, HLA-DR

Structure

Consists of one α (heavy) chain and β2-microglobulin;

peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and α2

Consists of α and β chains; peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and β1 domains

Function

Identifies and helps eliminate infected or malignant cells by presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells

Activates immune response by presenting exogenous antigens to CD4+ T-cells

Peptide Length

Presents shorter peptides (8-10 amino acids)

Presents longer peptides (10-30 amino acids)

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Immunoglobulin

Structure

Main Function

Location

IgA

Dimer (Secretory IgA), Monomer (Serum IgA)

Mucosal immunity

Mucosal secretions (saliva, tears, GI, respiratory)

IgG

Monomer

Long-term immunity, opsonization, complement activation

Blood, extracellular fluids, placenta (crosses)

IgM

Pentamer (with J chain)

Primary immune response, complement activation

Blood and lymphatic fluid

IgE

Monomer

Allergy, parasitic immunity

Bound to mast cells, basophils

IgD

Monomer

B-cell receptor function

Surface of immature B-cells

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Application Example

Homogeneous ELISA

One-step procedure; no separation of bound and free fractions needed.

Suitable for analysing haptens like drugs.

Enzyme-multiplied immunoassay technique (EMIT) for drug detection

Heterogeneous ELISA

Multi-step process requiring separation of bound and free fractions (e.g., by centrifugation).

Commonly used for microbial antigen and antibody detection.

Standard ELISA

Method

Description

Example

Sandwich ELISA

Used to detect antigens by capturing them between two antibodies (capture and detection antibodies).

Detection of rotavirus antigen in faeces

Indirect ELISA

Used to detect antibodies in the sample.

Anti-HIV antibody test

Competitive ELISA

Antigen in the sample competes with known antigen for a limited amount of antibody; produces an inverse curve (less colour at higher antigen levels).

Hapten detection

Capture ELISA

Highly specific for detecting specific antigens.

Various immunometric tests

Modification

Description and Application

Example

Cylinder/Cassette ELISA

For rapid, small-scale testing using disposable cassettes.

Results are read visually without special equipment.

Dot Blot Assay for HIV detection

Sandwich ELISA

Used specifically for antigen detection.

Detection of food toxins and adulterants

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Onset

Type I Early

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Hives, swelling, respiratory distress

Immediate (minutes)

Type I Delayed

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Wheezing, chest tightness, localized itching

Hours to days

Type II

Antibody-mediated cell destruction

Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia

Delayed (hours to days)

Type III

Immune complex deposition

Joint pain, fever, vasculitis

Delayed (hours to days)

Type IV

T-cell mediated response

Skin rash, contact dermatitis

Delayed (48-72 hours)

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to:
questions.explanation:
Stage

Process

Key Components

Initial B Cell Activation

1. Antigen Recognition:

  • B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD
  • Antigen internalization

2. Antigen Processing:

  • Processed into peptides
  • Loaded onto MHC-II molecules
  • B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD)
  • Surface immunoglobulins
  • MHC-II molecules

B Cell-T Cell Interaction

1. Signal Generation:

  • Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells
  • Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction
  • Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation

2. T Cell Help:

  • TH1: IFN-γ (IgG production)
  • TH2: IL-4 (IgE production)
  • TCR-MHC-II complex
  • CD40-CD40L
  • Cytokine receptors
  • Co-stimulatory molecules

B Cell Response

1. Germinal Center Formation:

  • B cell proliferation
  • Somatic hypermutation
  • Class switching

2. Differentiation:

  • • Into plasma cells
  • • Into memory B cells
  • Antibody production
  • Affinity maturation
  • Immunological memory

Outcomes

1. Immediate Response:

  • Antibody secretion
  • Different Ig classes based on cytokines

2. Long-term Response:

  • Memory formation
  • Enhanced secondary response
  • IgG, IgA, IgE production
  • High-affinity antibodies
  • Long-lived plasma cells
  • Memory B cells

questions.text: Which specific cell plays a role in type IV/delayed-type hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation:
T Helper Subset

Key Cytokines

Major Functions

Role in Immunity

TH1 Cells

• IL-2

• IFN-γ

• TNF-β

• Activate macrophages

• Enhance cell-mediated immunity

• Stimulate cytotoxic T cells

• Protection against intracellular pathogens

• Mediate delayed-type hypersensitivity

TH2 Cells

• IL-4

• IL-5

• IL-6

• IL-10

• IL-13

• Promote B cell proliferation

• Enhance antibody production

• Stimulate IgE class switching

• Promote eosinophil growth

• Protection against extracellular pathogens

• Mediate allergic responses

• Involved in helminth immunity

TH17 Cells

• IL-17

• IL-22

• Recruit neutrophils

• Enhance inflammation

• Promote tissue inflammation

• Protection at mucosal surfaces

• Involved in autoimmune diseases

• Contribute to inflammatory conditions

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.

A 6-month-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive. He is diagnosed with severe combined immunodeficiency due to an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible?
Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
Penicillin was given to the patient and immune hemolytic anemia develops. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Type 2

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is vaccination not contraindicated?
A person is found to have an absence of the CD40 marker. Which of the following would be seen?
Which blood is transfused in a patient with a Bombay blood group?

Besides NK cells, what other types of cells are capable of identifying and lysing target cells that have specific antibody-bound membrane surface antigens as part of their effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being stung by a bee while playing outside. Within minutes of the sting, he developed shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Timing

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Early Phase

Seconds to minutes

Mast cell/basophil degranulation: IgE cross-linking leads to the release of histamine and other mediators.

Skin: Urticaria (hives), itching (pruritus), erythema (redness), localized angioedema (swelling around lips, eyes)

Respiratory: Bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, sneezing, nasal congestion (allergic rhinitis)

Cardiovascular: Vasodilation and hypotension (drop in blood pressure), dizziness, syncope (fainting)

Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea due to smooth muscle contraction

Systemic Reaction: Anaphylaxis in severe cases, with generalized urticaria, angioedema, severe hypotension, and respiratory distress (life-threatening)

Late Phase

4–12 hours, peaks at 24–48 hours, lasting up to days

Inflammatory cell recruitment: Cytokines/chemokines attract eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, causing sustained inflammation.

Skin: Persistent redness, swelling, intense itching, and development of an eczema-like rash (seen in atopic dermatitis)

Respiratory: Recurrent bronchoconstriction, prolonged wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, mucus production, and airway hyperresponsiveness (chronic asthma exacerbation)

Eyes: Persistent redness and irritation in conjunctiva (allergic conjunctivitis)

Chronic Changes: In prolonged or recurrent reactions, there may be tissue remodeling, fibrosis, and thickening of affected areas (e.g., airways in asthma, skin in chronic dermatitis)

Type

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Onset

Type I Early

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Hives, swelling, respiratory distress

Immediate (minutes)

Type I Delayed

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Wheezing, chest tightness, localized itching

Hours to days

Type II

Antibody-mediated cell destruction

Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia

Delayed (hours to days)

Type III

Immune complex deposition

Joint pain, fever, vasculitis

Delayed (hours to days)

Type IV

T-cell mediated response

(Option D ruled out)

Skin rash, contact dermatitis

 

Delayed (48-72 hours)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding MHC molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells

options.label: B
options.text: The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway

options.label: C
options.text: MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

options.label: D
options.text: MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.correct_answer: C. MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
questions.explanation:
Correct option C - MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens:

Differences between MHC Class I and MHC Class II Molecules

 

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Present on

All nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Antigen-presenting cells (APCs)

Peptide antigen is

Presented to CD8 T cells

Presented to CD4 T cells

Nature of peptide antigen

Endogenous or intracellular (viral/tumor antigen)

Exogenous

Peptide antigen (size)

8-10 amino acid long

13-18 amino acid long

Antigen presentation pathways

Cytosolic pathway

Endocytic pathway

Peptide-binding site

alpha1/alpha2 groove

alpha1/beta1 groove

CD4 or CD 8 binding site

alpha 3 binds to CD8 molecules on Tc cells

beta 2 binds to CD4 on TH cells

questions.text: The following image depicts :
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Production of monoclonal

questions.text: Which one of the options below represents a site that has immunological privilege?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Seminiferous tubu

questions.text: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by ...
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Viru

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options triggers the classical complement cascade?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Ag - Ab

questions.text: Deficiency of which complement system increases the risk of N. meningitidis infection?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - C5-C9

Complement protein deficiencies 

Complement deficiencies 

Pathway(s) involved 

Disease/pathology 

C1, C2, C3, C4

C1, C2, C4 – classical pathway

C3 – common deficiency

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), glomerulonephritis and pyogenic infections

Properdin, Factor D

Alternative pathway

Neisseria and pyogenic infection

Membrane attack complex (C5-C9)

Common deficiency

Disseminated Neisseria infection

questions.text: Due to the lack of ________________, nude mice do not exhibit resistance to xenografts.
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - T C

questions.text: In the case of a 3-year-old child with a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms, which of the following is the most probable deficiency?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - IgG2

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not involve the use of antibody labeling?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an 11-year-old boy who presented at the pediatric outpatient department with multiple abscesses on his face, chest, and back, along with a history of frequent respiratory infections. Uponexamination, the child showed signs of atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back.
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Hyper IgE

questions.text: The classical complement pathway is activated by the binding of ............... ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Ag-A

questions.text: N. meningitidis can be caused by deficiency of ........... ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - C5-C9 D

Complement deficiency diseases

Complement deficiencies

Pathway(s) involved

Disease/pathology

Complement protein deficiencies

C1, C2, C3, C4

C1, C2, C4 – classical pathway

C3 – common deficiency

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), glomerulonephritis and pyogenic infections

Properdin, Factor D

Alternative pathway

Neisseria and pyogenic infection

Membrane attack complex (C5-C9)

Common deficiency

Disseminated Neisseria infection

Complement regulatory protein deficiencies

C1 esterase inhibitor

Overactive classical pathway

Hereditary angioneurotic edema

DAF (Decay accelerating factor) and CD59

Deregulated C3 convertase

Increased RBC lysis

PNH (Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria)

questions.text: In a case of chronic allergy, which immunoglobulin demonstrates increased levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - IgE

questions.text: Anaphylaxis occurred in a boy who was eating peanut butter. This scenario exemplifies:
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - IgE-Mediated R
